segments.text: And I won't name the specific organization.
But they have been given money, and a portion of that money
to John, but really not to John, but to John's operation that he has a little outfit over there, which is really for the secondary high school students, called Defense Studies.
And so, really, the money is really for his office costs, and the cost of Kathy Brown, and so on.
John came to the States, and this was in 79, I guess.
It was after the Senate had been formed and was in operation, and we were office members.
Brian was.
And he...
I went down to the Houston department.
We had a British army colonel who was also a research associate.
John got off the airplane, and although I had met him a couple of times before, I didn't know him all that well, but he was playing.
And Cole Hensley told me as we came out of the airport, got inside, and told me that John had discovered that this outfit in Washington
had put his name and resume on a proposal to the O.D.
without his approval.
That, in John's parlance, is just totally dishonest.
So, on the way, on the way home from Houston to Clarkville, John was sitting up front with me, and it comes to the second lap.
And John, of course, he's just a geek.
He's an avid conversationalist, and his mind is so active, it just leaps ahead.
It wears me out to talk with him.
But uncharacteristically, in this, all the way up here, he would talk animatedly for a while, and then he'd lapse into a silence.
And he was obviously there.
And he turned around to Colonel Hemsworth and said, John, I am really upset about that.
Talking about it.
And that must have happened 60 times, I guess.
Oh, he was just a slacker.
And so he came to Texas A&M.
He had breakfast with Colonel Hemsworth.
Well, in short, he had never seen a university like Texas.
And, of course, we, and being a military historian, he was obviously appreciative of the fact that it was a different institution than it had been.
I don't really know what he saw in the center, because we were very ill-formed at that time.
And I think that might have been attractive to him, because I think he feels and felt and feels very keenly about the need to train bright young people to do so.
And of course, he has his own standards and his own methodology for doing that.
And so I think he saw here a chance to help shape something that would fit the way he thinks.
It turns out that the philosophy that we have and that he has are very similar.
And I guess we probably ought to be more charitable and say that John's
John's view as a real genuine Soviet expert has colored my view of how Soviet studies ought to be done.
There's no question about it.
And so, yeah, I think we have at least in part been shaped by John.
So he, so then he went back, on his way back through Washington, he walked to Illinois, and he said, I want to work for the T.V.
in Illinois.
He said, I want to work for Texas A&M.
Well, it was a, it was an incredible coup for us, you see.
He was a guy with a well-established reputation, and so he worked.
And all of a sudden, all of his publications that he, that he publishes in the United States came to us.
So, going on the Center for Strategic Technology with John Erickson.
And so, we were able to ride John's coat tables into the Soviet research group.
And, now I don't, I should add, it has not, it has been a somewhat stormy relationship
John does not know the meaning of the word deadline.
The only time he worries about money is when he doesn't have any.
He's eccentric, difficult to get along with.
And so it's been a turbulent relationship.
John's reputation, although he has a reputation as a tremendous scholar, there are other aspects of his reputation that are not good.
He is well known for committing himself to go to a conference to present a paper.
I'm not sure of that.
For making commitments, and in defense of John, he will not say no.
And he and I now have become close enough friends where I can chastise him and say, John, God damn it, you must learn to say no.
It's unfair for you to tell people you'll do something and then not do it.
Quite, quite.
You're right, Dick.
And of course, it just... One thing's hitting one ear and out the other.
And...
But, you know, looking at the relationship on balance, I think it has been a very positive relationship for us.
But there have been some sponsors that because John has promised to deliver and hasn't, that we get, you know, to some extent we get tarred with that rush too.
So while it hasn't been a totally positive relationship, I think it's all very positive.
But he'll be here, hopefully, the setting's coming over in October.
And if it's not then, I'm sure he'll be here by January.
And I hope you get a chance to meet him.
He's incredible.
As I say, I think he has an understanding of the Soviet military very, very well.
It was quite a job.
Are there any other things you'd like to add about T's?
You've covered what your view is of the world, the function of T's, what should be and how it's changed.
Are there any particular memories you have of dealing with T's that you'd like to add?
No, I think I've probably related the essence of them all.
You know, it has been a

It's been, as far as I'm concerned, if Dick Thomas has had any success in this world, and whatever success lies ahead of me yet, that will be due in large part to T.S., which is undoubted, and to Harry Whitmore, and to Fred Benson, and to Skip Ford.
Skip and I may have different views, but we agree on enough things, you know, that it'll go on.
We're embarked on a new program now aimed at trying to get Texas A&M in a central position in this renaissance of space that has occurred.
And if that
If we're successful there, it will be because of teams.
I don't know that I could add much more.
I wish that TEAS had a little bit better relationship with the research foundation.
I think they don't often appreciate what a tremendous asset the foundation has.
The foundation's role has changed quite a lot over the last 20 years.
And a lot of people go, because government research has changed a lot over the last 20 years,
just the legal aspects of a contract with the government is incredibly more complex today than it was 20 years ago.
And other things like, you know, affirmative action and all of that sort of thing that administratively has to be taken toward the foundation of that.
So I'm not sure the T's, I don't think the relationship between the T's and the foundation
Years past, it used to be like that.
And now it's more like this.
But I hope that Tease can... Two things that I hope for Tease, I guess.
Forgive me if I'm airing dirty linen here or washing dirty linen.
Not quite in public, but I guess almost.
As you're probably aware, back when Benson was both dean and head of TEAS, there was a lot more congruence in the operations of the College of Engineering
and the Engineering Experiment Station than there was since Dr.
Page came in.
And again, you can't fault what Dr.
Page wanted to do.
But he wanted the College of Engineering to go in one direction, and Dr. Porter wanted it to go in another direction.

So we're now in a position now, as a guy who is principally teased, you know, I don't, it doesn't constrain my activities, but I know from my colleagues in aerospace engineering and in other departments that this dichotomy has caused us unsure of hell, frankly, in the past five years.
Dr.
Page wanted people to publish in the scholarly journals.
He saw his primary mission as raising the scholarly image of the College of the University, and God knows you can't find that.
However, when you have 500 faculty members,
And you have guys that haven't done that.
It's sort of like a reprise on the situation we had back, you know, in the early 60s, when we had department heads who were not research oriented.
Which is not to say they're not good guys, you know, like Al Crump and the rest of them.
But they were just trying to do things that those guys weren't equipped to handle.
And so, Dr.
Page wanted
500 faculty members to get in lockstep doing published research, scholarly research.
And we have guys that were hired principally to teach.
They were hired because they were great teachers, because they had a lot of industrial experience.
And preparing people for industry is still, I think, a major objective of the college.
Skip Porter is a very applied guy.
He wants to say TEAS, again, as you've probably been told, the Austin, that is the state view of TEAS, is that of an economic development agency.
It is not an educational function.
A lot of people don't realize that.
Well, that says Tease is going to do not necessarily a whole bunch of scholarly research.
And given Dr. Porter's industrial experience and having spent time at TI and so forth, why, he has a different view of the world than Dr.
Page has.
Here are these poor faculty members, and they don't know which guy to follow.
And Page controls their promotion and tenure, and Dr. Porter controls the seed money for their research.
We have 16 open positions in the Department of Electrical Engineering.
Sixteen!
Now you know why.
That's going to change.
The new super dean, whoever he is, hopefully will weld this thing back together into the unit it once was under Mr. Benson.
When I came here and was a department member in aerospace engineering, there was no
difference between what I, what, what Tease wanted me to do and what the department wanted me to do.
They were exactly congruent.
And that's why it was such a beautiful, beautiful set.
Now it's not.
And somehow, someway, we've got to get back to that.
And
This is not oral history, I guess.
Well, it will be.
Pardon me?
It will be.
Well, hopefully sometime.
It'll be interesting to see how it turns out, whether or not either or not.
You know, maybe it's irreversible.
I mean, maybe we can't get back to London.
I don't know.
All I can say is that the relationship between Pease and the College of Engineering today is not what it was
five years ago.
And I don't know, you know, maybe if you look at the, if you look at the legislation that set up TEAS back in 2014, was it?
As Dr. Porter said, we are the Texas Engineering Experiment Station.
We are not the Texas A&M Experiment Station.
And that's, you know, that says volumes.
We are, TEAS is here to serve the state.
Well, I don't know.
It may never ever be like it was before.
Quite like it was.
I kind of hope it will be because I think TEAS,
has been and can be the way by which we can get the right young people in here.
And, I mean, if you, you know, if we're in a situation where TEAS is like Southwest Research Institute or Mattel or, you know, going off its own very way, sort of,

maybe housed here on the Texas A&M campus, but really having very little to do with Texas A&M as such, or relatively little to do, then the College of Engineering is going to be like Georgia Tech was with me.
They're not going to have any money to work with.
And when a young guy comes in and says, well, do you have money for promoting research?
They'll say, yeah, you can take that out of your research money, like Georgia Tech told me.
And that ain't going to fly.
That's not going to watch.
So TEAS has been, I think, an enormous contributor to the growth of the university.
I think unquestionably the fact that we have the largest college of engineering in the country here is due to TEAS.
It's due, and TEAS has supported the evolution of the research program that has drawn Texas A&M a tremendous amount of respect.
Of course, we've always had that very, very strong undergraduate research program
And young people, I think, across the state of Texas still perceive a degree in engineering from Texas A&M to be a significant step up the ladder of success.
I think we're still, locally, that is within the state, I think our undergraduate education program is highly revered.
And I don't want to sacrifice that.
I think we need to hang on to that.
So I don't want to tease to do anything that would weaken that image.
I don't know.
It seems to me that there are people on up in the university

who are prepared to sacrifice that in order to achieve greatness, whatever that is, that we will become like MIT in the sense of having a pedestrian undergraduate program with a heavy focus on Nobel Prize winners and scholarly publications and all kinds of highfalutin research.
I think we have to remember that we are a land-grant institution.
We were established, like all other land-grant schools, prior to the enactment of the Morrill Act back in 1870 or thereabouts, higher education was the province of the wealthy.
And unless you were affluent, you just couldn't get a higher education.
And that's what the land grant schools were intended to do, to bring education to the masses.
And I'll be damned if I see any need to turn away from that.
I don't feel badly.
I mean, if I want to be a highfalutin guy, I'll go to Caltech or MIT.
And I just don't understand why
why some of our administration has to drive us away from that.
How many MITs do we need?
I think one's enough, really.
So I think we have contributed greatly to the state.
I think that the T's unquestionably, T's support and actions have undergirded the contribution that we've made to the state of Texas and to the nation.
And I just, I said maybe it is time to move on to some higher plateau.
Maybe this is what you're hearing is just the bleeding of a guy who's out of it, whose views are passe.
That could well be, I suppose.
Maybe I long for the good old days.
Of course, they say you can never go back.
Maybe there is some sort of a new relationship out there, a new framework in which T's can function effectively.
Could well be.
But if that means sacrificing what we have accomplished in the past, if it means destroying
the strengths on which this institution has been built.
I guess I'm reluctant to do that.
I don't see that it needs to be done.
I don't see why you have to destroy something in order to achieve something else.
Maybe you have to, but I don't see it.
So I think TEAS has been an absolutely great institution.
in terms of what it's done for the nation, for the state, for the university, and of course for Dick Thomas.
I think that it may be necessary to
to change the road that we're on, or the path that we're on again.
And we're going to continue to provide that kind of support.
Well, I don't know.
Obviously, my admiration and respect of T's is unbounded, because I've been fortunate enough to have
been a part of it in its formative years, shall we say, when it really grew and really blossomed.
I kind of wish that other institutions could see what TEAS has done for Texas A&M and for the state and could learn from that.
and maybe replicate it in some form or other.
Because I think it can serve other states as well as it has served Texas with the proper leadership.
And again, I'm not going to agree it's important.
It obviously has to have a...
a good view of the kind of contribution that it can make and the kind of strengths that it has to have to make this contribution.
So with proper leadership, I think that TEAS and other states could be as effective as it has been doing.
Well, thank you for all your time.
